intro: Atriplex subconferta, commonly known as the narrowleaf saltbush, is a shrub native to the arid and semi-arid regions of western North America. It is characterized by its small, oval-shaped leaves that are often covered in a layer of fine, white powder, which helps reduce water loss in dry environments. The plant produces small, greenish-yellow flowers arranged in clusters, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. Its deep root system allows it to thrive in poor, saline soils, making it an important species in stabilizing sandy or disturbed landscapes. Atriplex subconferta is also valued for its ability to provide forage for wildlife and livestock in harsh conditions.
